Organize Products into Categories for B2B Commerce for Visualforce

Organize products into logical categories and subcategories for buyers who prefer a natural taxonomy of information. You can define multiple levels of subcategories. For example, coffee products can belong to a Medium or Dark category, and both of those categories can belong to a parent category named Coffee.

REQUIRED EDITIONS AND USER PERMISSIONS

Salesforce Compatibility

Salesforce Classic (not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.




B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)


USER PERMISSIONS NEEDED
To create CC Category records:	Create on CC Categories
To access CC Admin and change settings:	Access B2B Commerce for Visualforce Admin Settings permission set
To assign CC Products to CC Categories:	Create on CC Product Categories

The categories that you create display in the Category Tree widget.

To manage category records for your storefronts, create the following CC Category records:

Storefront Root Category (1)
The parent record for all categories on a particular storefront.

In the Capricorn Coffee demo storefront data, the storefront root category is a CC Category record named CoffeeRoot with a Category ID of COFFEE-ROOT.

Storefront Categories (2)
The categories that roll up to the storefront root category.
Storefront Subcategories (3)
The categories that roll up to a storefront category (2).
NOTE The Category Tree widget can show at most four levels of subcategories under each category.
Create a root category for your storefront.
On the CC Categories tab in your org, click New.
For Category Name, enter a name that identifies the record as the root category for your storefront, such as CoffeeRoot.
TIP This name doesn't display on the storefront. Choose a name that's helpful for you when managing category records.
For Category ID, enter a unique value that B2B Commerce for Visualforce uses to programmatically reference the category, such as COFFEE-ROOT.
For End Date, select a date far in the future, since you probably don't want your root category record to expire.
Save your changes.
Create a category record for one of your storefront's top-level categories, such as Coffee Machines.
On the CC Categories tab in your org, click New.
For Category Name, enter the name that you want to show on the storefront for the category, such as Coffee Machines.
For Category ID, enter a unique value that B2B Commerce for Visualforce uses to programmatically reference the category, such as COFFEE-MACHINES.
If you've enabled friendly URLs as part of your storefront's SEO strategy, enter the category's friendly URL value in the SEO ID field.
For Parent Category, search for the storefront root category you created in step 1.
Enter a Sequence value.
NOTE To determine the order of categories on a storefront, B2B Commerce for Visualforce compares the Sequence values of all CC Categories records with the same Parent Category value. For example, let’s say that you have two top-level categories. One category has a sequence of 100, and the other has a sequence of 200. The category with the value 100 displays first, and the category with the value 200 displays second.
For ShortDescRT, enter a description for the category, which displays on the Product List page.
TIP The ShortDesc, LongDesc, and LongDescRT fields aren't used by the managed package.
Save your changes.
To nest a subcategory under a top-level category, create another category record. Repeat step 2, making sure that you select the correct parent category.
NOTE Each category record provides a Child Category Count field. However, by default the B2B Commerce for Visualforce managed package doesn't reference or update this field.
Create other category and subcategory records needed for your product taxonomy by repeating steps 2 and 3.
Update your storefront settings with the root category you created in step 1.
On the CC Admin tab in your org, select your storefront (1).
In the Storefront Settings menu, select General (2).
For Root Category ID, enter the value from the Category ID record you created for the storefront root category, such as COFFEE-ROOT.
Click Save.
Refresh the category tree cache.
Assign products to your categories and subcategories.

For example, assign a coffee machine to the Coffee Machines category created in step 2.

TIP The Product Count field on each category record automatically updates when you assign products. You can assign a product to multiple categories.
On the CC Products tab in your org, select a product.
Go to the Product Categories related list, and click New.
In Category, select the product that you want to assign the product to, such as Coffee Machines.
Enter a Sequence value.
NOTE To determine the order of products within a category, B2B Commerce for Visualforce compares the Sequence values of all CC Product Category records with the same category. For example, let’s say that you have two products assigned to the same category. One product's CC Product Category record has a sequence of 100, and the other has a sequence of 200. The product with the value 100 displays first, and the product with the value 200 displays second.
Click Save.
Guidelines for Category Images for B2B Commerce for Visualforce
Complement your storefront's branded experience with category-specific images that appear when buyers browse your categories on the Product List page.
Localize Categories for an Internationalized Storefront
If your storefront supports more than one locale, localize your category records for each of your supported languages.
Refresh the Category Tree Cache
To help storefront pages quickly load the Category Tree widget, B2B Commerce for Visualforce caches the categories data you've created. Refresh the cache after you update your category records to ensure that the storefront always references the most recent category data.
